I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB),  in  association  with  European  Bank  for 
Reconstruction  and  Development  (EBRD)  and  International  Finance  Corporation  (IFC),  is 
supporting  the  Government  of  Uzbekistan  and  Uzbek  Telecom  (UT)  to  strengthen  the 
telecommunications  regulatory  environment,  while  identifying  opportunities  to  improve  the 
profitability of UT in preparation for privatization. In early August 2002, a joint mission of ADB, 
IFC,  and  EBRD  agreed  to  collaborate  to  provide  technical  assistance  (TA)  to  assist  UT 
restructure its operations along commercial lines. This understanding has been confirmed with 
the Government in a letter jointly issued by EBRD, IFC, and ADB on 8 November 2002. Subject 
to the findings of the TA, the international financial institutions (IFIs) may consider the provision 
of a preprivatization loan (PPL) to help facilitate the privatization of the UT’s operations. As per 
the understanding reached, EBRD will provide support to review the regulatory framework of 
UT,  IFC  will  help  develop  a  business  plan,  and  ADB  will  support  the  development  of  a 
management information system (MIS) for UT. ADB’s proposed TA will help UT develop cost-
based tariffs and enable accurate monitoring of financial performance against business plan 
projections. The TA framework is in Appendix 1.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Reform of Large Utilities. In line with the broader macroeconomic stabilization program 
and structural reforms, the Government  is undertaking preparatory work to restructure large 
utilities  in  the  telecommunications,  oil  and  gas,  and  power  sectors  to  remove  critical 
infrastructure  bottlenecks,  reduce  production  costs  by  pursuing  industrial  deregulation  to 
increase the level of competition, and improve the ability of large utilities to access capital and 
skills  through  privatization.  The  State  Property  Committee  (GKI),  in  association  with  the 
Privatization Bureau, has been implementing case-by-case privatization, financed by a World 
Bank Loan. As part of this program, GKI has launched reforms in the telecommunications sector 
where  domestic  and  international  operations  have  been  merged  to  create  UT,  and  a 
privatization advisor, Commerzbank, has been engaged to advise on restructuring with a view to 
preparing UT for eventual privatization. In the natural resources sector, the Government has 
decided to privatize the national oil and gas company, UzbekNefteGaz. In the power sector, GKI 
is recruiting a consultant for Uzbek Energo to advise on industry restructuring, regulation, and 
privatization options. In the rail sector, GKI is assessing the privatization potential of a number 
of companies. 
 
3.  Telecommunications Sector.  The fixed telecommunications network suffers from very 
low coverage because of years of underinvestment. In Uzbekistan, currently, penetration rate of 
about 6.5 telephone lines for every 100 inhabitants is low (compared with Russia where the 
penetration rate is 21%) and has not risen over the years. In contrast supported by enhanced 
competition, the mobile sector has seen considerable growth. Despite this, the present six 
mobile operators have managed to achieve a national penetration rate of only about  0.4%, 
which is still lower than that of Russia (2.3%). 
 
4.  The telecommunications sector policy and regulatory framework has been the subject of 
a detailed review funded by the Technical Assistance Program for the Commonwealth of 
Independent States (TACIS). On the basis of the review, the Government has unbundled the 
sector somewhat by separating policy and regulatory functions from service provision. Under

the present arrangement, since July 2000 the Communications and Information Agency of 
Uzbekistan (CIAU) now handles the policy and regulatory functions, while UT provides for fixed 
line services. UT was subsequently corporatized and its ownership now rests fully with GKI.   
 
5.  The Government has promulgated the new telecommunications law and developed a 
conceptual framework to introduce fundamental principles of competition and modern regulation 
in the telecommunications sector. UT has a market share of 98% in the local fixed line and 95% 
in the long-distance fixed-line subsector. The privatization advisor, Commerzbank, has been 
appointed to facilitate the divestiture of UT. The Government plans to sell 51–75% of UT's 
shares  to  a  strategic  shareholder.  Commerzbank  has  advised  on,  and  supervised  further 
restructuring of UT's operations by  merging UT’s 12 regional operating companies. UT has 
invested heavily in the national network, with 8 of 12 regional centers already being connected 
by fiber optic cable. It is expected that the other four centers, which were connected by radio-
relay lines, will be connected with the general network by fiber optic lines by 2003. 
 
6.  Despite  the  progress  of  structural  reforms  in  the  telecommunications  sector,  the 
Government  has  yet  to  develop  an  independent  regulator  and  draw  up  a  timetable  for 
introducing competition in basic telecommunications services. The tariff structure of UT needs to 
be revised to reflect the actual costs of provision. The UT enterprise-restructuring program 
began on 27 December 2001 following the Decision of the Cabinet of Ministers #488. At the 
same time, further work is required to transform UT into a commercially viable company. There 
is significant under capacity in some areas of the fixed-line network. For instance, in October 
2000 Commerzbank estimated there was a waiting list of 33,577 people.2  At the same time, 
there is significant excess capacity in the national network due to low levels of digitized access 
lines that would allow data communication services.   
 
7.  UT's financial statements for 2001 and for the first half of 2002 have been revised in line 
with International Accounting Standards (IAS). The latest accounts indicate that despite stable 
growth of revenue in national currency, the revenue of UT in US dollars decreased over the last 
years  because  the  growth  of  tariffs  lagged  behind  the  growth  of  the  US  dollar  rate. 
Consequently, UT has accumulated a substantial level of debt (close to $170 million), which is 
beyond its debt servicing capacity in relation to its revenues and cash flows. This debt burden, 
coupled with the weak financial performance of UT, makes it difficult for the IFIs to consider at 
this time a PPL that would help attract strong strategic partners to UT in the future. To enable 
the IFIs and any strategic investor to consider this PPL, UT will need to substantially improve its 
performance and transform itself into a commercially viable and attractive investment candidate.  
 
8.  To support this approach, the Government and the aid agencies have developed an 
integrated program of TA to develop a PPL to support restructuring UT. The proposed TA 
program will build on the work done by TACIS during 1999-2001 to modernize and liberalize the 
telecommunications sector and prepare for the proposed privatization of UT.  EBRD’s TA will 
assist UT carry through the proposed regulatory reforms needed to remove conflicts of interest 
in regulation, and provide the basis for allowing UT to charge efficient commercially sustainable 
tariffs. A further requirement for establishing UT as a commercially viable entity is a business 
plan, and IFC will finance this activity. Underpinning both the upgrading of the regulatory 
framework and the successful implementation of the business plan is a fully automated MIS 
based on IAS, and this initiative is the focus of the proposed TA.  The work done in this TA will 
be closely coordinated with reforms supported by ADB in the areas of corporate governance 
and enterprise restructuring.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
9.  The TA will provide  UT with a modern MIS based on an IAS accounting system that 
would allow it to (i) improve understanding of its cost structure and key profitability drivers; 
(ii) derive cost-based tariffs, which in turn will help the telecommunications regulatory body 
establish an appropriate tariff framework for the sector; (iii) monitor its budgeted versus actual 
financial performance; and (iv) make appropriate operational and strategic business decisions.      
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  The  TA  will  be  in  four stages: stage 1–development of the accounting, budgeting, 
investment  planning,  and  reporting  framework;  stage  2–detailed  design  of  accounting, 
budgeting, investment planning, and reporting procedures; stage 3–development of customized 
accounting and MIS designed to accommodate the framework and procedures; and stage 4–
preparation and implementation of a training program for management and staff. 
 
11.  The TA will include the following activities:   
 
(i)  Conduct interviews with senior management, prepare  a  preliminary  business 
diagnosis of UT, identify existing accounting system and MIS and procedures, 
and  specify  the  conceptual  parameters  of  the  accounting  and  management 
reporting  system  that  will  be  implemented—the accounting, budgeting, and 
investment  planning  concept  will  define  the  principles  of  the  accounting, 
budgeting,  investment  planning,  and  reporting  process,  the  distribution  of 
responsibilities in the planning and reporting process (vertical and horizontal); 
identify the accounting, budgeting,  and investment decision-making principals; 
identify the statutory accounting and management information needs; and outline 
basic planning, management, and accounting reporting forms. 
 
(ii)  Develop a system of key performance indicators (KPIs) and normative standards 
that underpin the critical revenue, cost, and profitability drivers for planning, 
control, and benchmarking of the revenue and costs of various business levels of 
the organization. Detailed planning and reporting forms and procedures based on 
IAS will be developed to coordinate the accounting, budgeting, and reporting 
process to provide a basis for subsequent timely and effective evaluation of 
commercial  performance  by  management  and  shareholders;  the  roles  and 
responsibilities of each of the involved parties in the management reporting 
process will be formally identified and agreed-upon. 
 
(iii)  Develop a computerized accounting system and MIS that will provide UT with the 
capability  to  operationalize  the  budget,  investment,  and  reporting  framework 
developed in stage 2. Specifically, the MIS will provide KPIs and planning and 
reporting forms for budgeting units and each responsibility and analytical center 
within UT, supported by a manual for using the MIS; the system will be tested 
with UT staff. 
 
(iv)  Prepare and implement appropriate training programs for management and staff. 
The training program will provide management and staff with the necessary skills

4 
and  information  needed  to  implement  the  accounting,  budgeting,  investment 
planning, and reporting framework and procedures using the computerized MIS. 
 
(v)  Based on (i) to (iv) above, formulate selected components of the PPL that will 
guide the commercial restructuring of UT. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The total cost of the TA is estimated to be $600,000 equivalent, comprising $375,000 in 
foreign exchange and $225,000 equivalent in local currency. The Government has requested 
ADB to provide the entire foreign exchange cost and $25,000 equivalent in local currency. The 
Government will provide $200,000 equivalent in counterpart facilities. The TA will be financed 
on a grant basis by ADB's TA funding program.  Details of the cost estimates are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  UT will be the Executing Agency for the TA.  The TA activities will be closely coordinated 
with  the  TA  being  provided  by  EBRD  in  telecommunications  regulation,  and  by  IFC  in 
developing the business plan for UT.   
 
14.  ADB will select and engage a firm using the quality–and cost–based selection method 
and a simplified technical proposal in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
and other arrangements for selecting and engaging domestic consultants. Consulting services 
of 16 persons–months will be required: 8 international and 8 domestic. The consultant team will 
comprise three international consultants and two domestic consultants, with relevant experience 
in developing accounting systems and MIS based on IAS in the region. Appendix 3 gives the 
outline terms of reference for the consultants.  
 
15.  The TA is expected to begin in March 2003 and will be implemented over a period of 
8 months, finishing in June 2004. Activities in stage 1 will take 1.5 months and involve a series 
of preliminary meetings between the consultants and UT management so they can explain the 
work program. The business diagnostic will then be prepared and will be used to develop the 
accounting, budgeting, and investment-planning concept. An inception report will be submitted 
2 weeks after project inception, and an interim report defining the business concept will be 
submitted 1.5 months after project inception. The findings of the business concept will be 
discussed and agreed-upon with UT's management team and the IFIs. Stage 2 will take 
2 months, and the key output will  be  a second interim report detailing the design of the 
accounting, budgeting, investment-planning, and reporting procedures for UT. Stage 3 will take 
2 months to implement, and the outputs will be a third interim report, accompanied by a 
computerized accounting system and MIS, and a manual that reflects the business concept 
prepared in stage 2. Stage 4 will take 2 weeks; during this time, the consultants will submit an 
agreed-upon training program to UT's management and staff, and present a draft final report 
that will be finalized following the approval of UT management and the IFIs. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance, not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Uzbekistan for the Developing a Management Information System for Uzbek 
Telecom, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Expertise Required and Recruited on Firm Level 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will be implemented over an 8-month period. The Asian 
Development Bank will recruit an international consulting firm to provide 8 person-months of 
consulting services. The consultant team will consist of a team leader (international, 3 person-
months) and two international team members, each providing 2.5 person-months of inputs. The 
international team of consultants will be supported by domestic consultants (8 person-months) 
with  expertise  in  accounting  and  management  information  system  (MIS)  design  and 
implementation, based on International Accounting Standards (IAS) principles and systems. 
Both the international and domestic consultants will perform the consulting tasks identified in 
para. 4.  
 
1.  Accounting and MIS Specialist/Team Leader (international, 3 person-months) 
 
2.  The team leader will be a specialist in establishing accounting systems and MIS based 
on IAS, with appropriate work and educational qualifications; have sufficient knowledge of 
identifying  management  and  statutory  accounting  and  financial  information  needs  for 
commercial  enterprises;  will  be  familiar  with  designing  and  implementing  an  automated 
accounting system and MIS using appropriate personal computer (PC)-based technology; will 
have experience in training management and staff in accounting and MIS concepts based on 
IAS; and will have adequate knowledge or working experience in the former Soviet Union. The 
team leader will be responsible for overall TA implementation, prepare required reports, and 
coordinate with Uzbek Telecom (UT) management, Communications and Information Agency of 
Uzbekistan (CIAU), the Government, and international financial institutions (IFIs). 
 
2.  Accounting and MIS Consultants  (international, 5 person-months; domestic, 
8 person-months) 
 
3.  The accounting and MIS consultants will have experience in establishing accounting 
systems, and MIS based on IAS, with appropriate work and educational background.  Skills 
required  will  include  knowledge  of  statutory  and  management  information  requirements; 
familiarity with developing accounting, budgeting, and investment-planning systems; developing 
procedures and reporting forms; conducting organizational reviews and identifying management 
responsibilities and information needs; reviewing information technology (IT) hardware and 
software;  evaluating  alternative  PC-based  platforms  for  accounting  systems  and  MIS; 
developing the accounting and MIS; preparing accounting and MIS manuals; and designing and 
implementing training programs for management and staff. 
 
B.  Consulting Tasks at Firm Level 
 
4.  Consulting tasks will include, but will not be limited to the following: 
 
1.  Stage  1:  Development  of  the  Accounting  System,  Budgeting,  and 
Investment-Planning Framework 
 
(i)  Conduct interviews with CIAU to gain an understanding of information needs for 
developing cost-based tariffs.

Appendix 3  9 
(ii)  Conduct interviews with UT senior management to gain an understanding of 
existing accounting systems and MIS, reporting arrangements, decision-making 
responsibilities, and current business plan.   
 
(iii)  Identify UT's accounting, budgeting, and investment decision-making principals, 
and  the  distribution  of  responsibilities  in  the  planning  and  reporting  process 
(vertical and horizontal). 
 
(iv)  Identify the statutory accounting and management information needs of UT.  
Identify management and financial information gaps, and evaluate alternative 
organization and reporting arrangements that will provide accounting information 
based on IAS, supported by indicators of financial performance. 
 
(v)  Prepare a preliminary business diagnosis of UT, define the principles for a 
proposed accounting, budgeting, and investment planning process, and provide 
an outline of accounting, budgeting and investment planning procedures, and 
basic planning and reporting forms that management will need to manage UT on 
a commercial basis.  
 
(vi)  Specify the conceptual parameters for a proposed accounting and management 
reporting  system  that  will  be  implemented,  and  present  findings  to  UT 
management, CIAU, the Government, and IFIs. 
 
2.  Stage  2:  Detailed  Design  of  Accounting,  Budgeting  and  Investment 
Planning Procedures and Management Reporting Package and Procedures 
 
(i)  Develop key performance indicators (KPIs) and normative standards for the 
critical revenue, cost, and profitability drivers to plan, control, and benchmark the 
revenue and costs of various business levels within UT. 
 
(ii)  Prepare detailed planning and reporting forms based on IAS standards and 
develop procedures to coordinate the budgeting and reporting processes and 
ensure that the accounting system and MIS provide UT management with timely 
effective information that will enable it to evaluate commercial performance and 
take necessary decisions on an informed basis.   
 
(iii)  Define  the  roles  and  responsibilities  of  each  of  the  parties  involved  in  the 
management reporting process. 
 
(iv)  Present detailed framework and MIS procedures to UT management, CIAU, the 
Government, and IFIs and obtain agreement on the proposed approach. 
 
3.  Stage  3:  Development  of  Customized  Accounting  System  and  MIS 
Designed to Accommodate the Proposed Framework and Procedures 
 
(i)  Develop a computerized accounting system and MIS that will provide UT with the 
capability  to  operationalize  the  budget,  investment,  and  reporting  framework 
developed in stage 2.  Specifically, the MIS will provide KPIs and planning and 
reporting forms for budgeting units and each responsibility and analytical center 
within UT.

(ii)  Prepare  manuals  and  present  accounting  system  and  MIS  for  testing  and 
evaluation by management and staff, in consultation with the Government, CIAU, 
and IFIs. 
 
4.  Stage  4:  Preparation  and  Implementation  of  Training  Program  for 
Management and Staff 
 
(i)  Develop and implement training programs for management and staff on the 
accounting,  budgeting,  investment  planning,  and  reporting  framework  and 
procedures. 
 
(ii)  Develop and implement training programs for management and staff on the use 
of the computerized accounting system and MIS. 
 
C.  Expected Results and Deliverables 
 
5.  Results and deliverables will be the responsibility of the consulting firm. Expected results 
are a business diagnostic detailing management information and reporting needs; a business 
concept that outlines UT's required accounting, budgeting, and planning procedures; definition 
of  reporting  arrangements  and  decision-making  responsibilities;  an  automated  accounting 
system and MIS, supported by user manuals; and training materials. 
 
6.  The consultant will submit an inception report 2 weeks after starting the project. An 
interim report that contains a business diagnostic and defines the business concept will be 
submitted after 1.5 months.  At stage 2, a second interim report will be submitted, detailing the 
design of the accounting, budgeting, and investment planning procedures and management 
reporting package and procedures for UT. At stage 3, a third interim report will be submitted, 
accompanied by the computerized accounting system and MIS, and a manual that reflects the 
business concept prepared in stage 2. At stage 4 the consultants will submit an agreed-upon 
training program to UT management and staff and present a draft final report that will be 
finalized following review by UT management and IFIs.
